==Similarities between ''Suite FranÃ§aise'' and other novels==
==Similarities between ''Suite FranÃ§aise'' and other novels==
â
[[File:Yellow tapers.jpg|200px|right]] Some readers have noticed similarities between [[Bruce Marshall]]'s 1943 novel ''[[Yellow Tapers for Paris]]'' and [[IrÃ¨ne NÃ©mirovsky]]'s ''Suite FranÃ§aise''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hankarcher.blogspot.com/2011/01/yellow-tapers-for-paris-suite-francaise.html|title=Yellow Tapers for Paris & Suite FranÃ§aise|publisher=http://hankarcher.blogspot.com}}</ref> which was written at about the same time, but not discovered until 1998. There is no suggestion of [[plagiarism]] -- NÃ©mirovsky had been murdered before Marshall's novel was published and no one saw NÃ©mirovsky's work before its 1998 discovery. Both works have major characters who work in finance: Marshall's [[protagonist]] is an [[accountant]] while NÃ©mirovsky's work has several characters who work for a [[bank]]. Both books were written during and/or immediately after the events in question, but show significant reflection; they are not autobiographical works, but fiction featuring invented characters. The stories cover the leadup to the [[Battle of France|Nazi invasion]] and its immediate aftermath, but the events of the respective stories are much different. Marshall's ends before the [[occupation]], while NÃ©mirovsky's has significant portions devoted to it.
+
Some readers have noticed similarities between [[Bruce Marshall]]'s 1943 novel ''[[Yellow Tapers for Paris]]'' and [[IrÃ¨ne NÃ©mirovsky]]'s ''Suite FranÃ§aise''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hankarcher.blogspot.com/2011/01/yellow-tapers-for-paris-suite-francaise.html|title=Yellow Tapers for Paris & Suite FranÃ§aise|publisher=http://hankarcher.blogspot.com}}</ref> which was written at about the same time, but not discovered until 1998. There is no suggestion of [[plagiarism]] -- NÃ©mirovsky had been murdered before Marshall's novel was published and no one saw NÃ©mirovsky's work before its 1998 discovery. Both works have major characters who work in finance: Marshall's [[protagonist]] is an [[accountant]] while NÃ©mirovsky's work has several characters who work for a [[bank]]. Both books were written during and/or immediately after the events in question, but show significant reflection; they are not autobiographical works, but fiction featuring invented characters. The stories cover the leadup to the [[Battle of France|Nazi invasion]] and its immediate aftermath, but the events of the respective stories are much different. Marshall's ends before the [[occupation]], while NÃ©mirovsky's has significant portions devoted to it.
"Dolce," the second part of ''Suite FranÃ§aise,'' is also similar to ''[[Le Silence de la mer|Le Silence de la Mer]]'', a novella by the French author Vercors (pseudonym of [[Jean Bruller]]). Both stories deal with a German officer, who in civilian life was a composer, who is quartered in the house of a young French woman. Both ''Suite FranÃ§aise,'' and ''Le Silence de la Mer'' were finished in early 1942.
"Dolce," the second part of ''Suite FranÃ§aise,'' is also similar to ''[[Le Silence de la mer|Le Silence de la Mer]]'', a novella by the French author Vercors (pseudonym of [[Jean Bruller]]). Both stories deal with a German officer, who in civilian life was a composer, who is quartered in the house of a young French woman. Both ''Suite FranÃ§aise,'' and ''Le Silence de la Mer'' were finished in early 1942.
